description:
Human astrovirus BF34 is a member of the Astroviridae family, which are small, non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses. Astroviruses are known to infect a variety of mammalian and avian hosts, including humans.

Human astrovirus BF34 is a specific strain or genotype of human astrovirus that has been identified and characterized through genetic analysis. Like other human astroviruses, BF34 is primarily associated with causing acute gastroenteritis, particularly in young children and immunocompromised individuals.

The viral genome of human astrovirus BF34 contains approximately 6.8 kilobases and encodes three major open reading frames (ORFs) that are responsible for the production of the viral structural and non-structural proteins. Phylogenetic analysis has shown that BF34 belongs to the classical human astrovirus genotype, which includes several other well-known strains that have been detected in human populations around the world.

Further research is ongoing to better understand the epidemiology, clinical manifestations, and potential public health implications of human astrovirus BF34 and other related astrovirus strains.
